title: "Just mute" is for the birds
body:
The whole idea that it's up to the typical player to "just mute" to avoid conflict, is nonsense. The problem lies in the fact that trolls are desperate for attention--if you mute them, they escalate their in-game behavior to flashing on top of you, running into your lane and inting repeatedly, etc. (don't tell me this is a fringe case either, see below)

Recently since my account has been banned, I've been playing on a smurf, muting all from the beginning so that I won't be "toxic". Ironically, what I've found is, I get griefed significantly MORE often for muting other players and not talking to them. 

Finally, I think the logic that someone should get banned for addressing a griefer or troll is fundamentally wrong. If I'm driving my car, and someone runs a red light at double the speed limit, that driver loses their license, gets a ticket, etc. My driving privileges are not affected if I flip him the bird, or say something inflammatory because of what they did.

That driver doesn't lose shit if the cops don't get called. You giving them the finger just gives them the attention they were seeking with no consequences for their actions. Also, you can indeed get pulled over and ticketed for flipping the bird if a cop catches you. I've seen it happen, so don't assume you're safe from consequences when you do something stupid.

Same concept in any online, multiplayer game. If you give trolls attention, they get what they want and continue to keep doing it. If everyone could just stop giving tolls what they want, then eventually they'd leave because they'd no longer be having fun like they were before.

And how can you be sure they're griefing more because you muted them? Did you tell them you muted them? If so, then yeah they're going to escalate to doing worse stuff to get a rise out of you. But if they don't know you muted them, then high chance is they would've done that even if you didn't mute them. Heck, I've had games where NO ONE spoke... and had someone inting. Muting someone doesn't mean they're going to do worse unless you tell them you muted them.

Also, you don't get punished for addressing a troll. It's how you do it that gets you. Going, "Can you please stop?" wont get you punished, but saying, "stop fucking trolling you ass." will. If you can't be calm and collected and nice/neutral when addressing something, then all you're doing is making the situation worse for the other players in the game.

Mute, report, move on. And don't respond or stoop to their level. All you're doing is giving them what they want.

> Also, you can indeed get pulled over and ticketed for flipping the bird if a cop catches you.
> 

False, US Supreme court determined this to be free speech.

> I've seen it happen, so don't assume you're safe from consequences when you do something stupid.
 
Don't make stuff up. 

Besides nullifying free speech, do you also believe that the driver should lose their license for behavior unrelated to the actual act of driving itself?

The main difference is that chatting in-game is not considered "free speech".  We all agree to Riot's ToS when playing, for better or worse. The irony is that while we all "agree" to their terms, I'd be willing to bet that a very, very small minority abides by them fully. If the terms were enforced as written, most of the community would be banned. 

There's a lot of discontent with the way bans are handled among the community (outside of this Board Sub). Ultimately, Riot panders to trolls, hiding behind arguments like, "well we just can't tell if they were intentionally performing badly" etc. The banning of passionate players has done nothing but harm their game overall, at least in my opinion.

Yeah, their terms are not reflective of the way the real world works. Taking property from someone that they paid for on the basis of chat logs is utter nonsense. But of course, their "terms" stipulate that even though you paid for it, you have no claim over it. I personally can't wait for digital content laws to be updated to the 21st century. A lot of corporations have an awakening coming.

Free speech doesn't free of consequence. And watching my sister get pulled over is making shit up? Cool, all tell her to tell the police that next time they ask about it.

Depends on what they do. You're not supposed to take your eyes off the road, but a lot of people do that to flip others off. So yeah, if thy're doing that and endangering other drivers, yes they should.

If she did get pulled over and ticketed, it wouldn't hold up in court because it's considered free speech per the federal government. If she incited violence or committed another offense, then she can be held accountable for that offense.  

Driving like a maniac and acting like you own the road, flipping people off, is not the same as a reactionary flip off to someone else who broke the laws. You cannot tell me that reacting to someone in this manner is justification for revocation of their driving privileges. Honestly, you are grasping at straws, have anything better to add?

I'll be sure to ask your sister all about it ;)

To not act like a child and keep saying it's free speech like that means anything? Again, free speech doesn't mean free of consequence.

And maybe it's different in your area, but my sister had to pay the ticket even when she tried to get rid of it. It was considered, I may be using the wrong words here so bear with me, egging on the other driver.

With all due respect, this is determined to be a freedom by the US Supreme Court--your local government cannot renege on that. In this conversation, free speech **does **mean without legal consequence. In the situation I mentioned, it has been determined not to have a legal consequence. The exceptions to free speech are when you incite violence etc. Rude speech is still free speech, as determined by the USC. If the speech violates contractual agreements (despite being free, legally), you can face consequences per that agreement, too. Hence bans via Riot's ToS. The point I wanted to make, is that the logic behind Riot's ToS is fundamentally flawed.

??? Trolls want attention. They want you to flame. This has been proven by multiple large-scale scientific studies.

In fact, by muting the trolls, they are much more likely to stop trolling as they aren’t getting the reaction they want from you.

They do want attention, which is why muting them causes their in-game behavior to escalate to flashing on you randomly, ulting in your direction for no apparent reason, inting, etc. 

Muting them absolutely is not helping, re-read my post.

Except... it doesn’t. By flaming them back, they know they’re getting a reaction out of you, thus they’re going to troll more. **This has been proven scientifically**.

If you ignore them, they may very well try harder, but that makes them more likely to get banned for trolling.

Anecdotally, this has not been my experience since creating a fresh account and muting all every game. If you're going to invoke "science" cite a source specific to this case, that has been peer-reviewed. As it is, Riot is not as efficient at banning actual player behavior such as inting or trolling, as compared to chat offenses. Your claims are most likely dubious and unfounded, since the actual data pertinent to the discussion likely doesn't exist.

Muting people who are not being toxic in chat is going to cause tension, yes.

Players will get frustrated when they are not able to communicate with you, or they think you are ignoring them since you muted them and cannot see things.

I’m not sure if you’ve heard of [Google Scholar](https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C44&q=internet+trolls&btnG=) but it’s very useful for things like this. I encourage you to peruse the science behind internet trolls.

You've contradicted yourself a bit:
-They try harder to get at you when ignored
-Muting them "scientifically" reduces their trolling

Which is it? 

I'm well-versed in studies, I've actually made some contributions in condensed matter research. Instead of making broad statements about trolls, send me the specific study regarding my argument, with supporting data from Riot Games.

They may try harder in your game, but that makes them more likely to get banned. They can’t be trolling if they don’t have an account. Most of them understand this, so won’t “try harder”.

In future games, they’re much less likely to be trolls if you don’t feed them.

> Most of them understand this, so won’t “try harder”.

Can you corroborate that statement? As mentioned several times, this has not been my personal experience. I'm fine with being an outlier, but if you're making a statement to the contrary, I'd like to see the evidence you keep purporting.

Furthermore, I'm not convinced on the efficacy of permanent bans to begin with. There is such a wide availability of botted accounts that people always find a way back on to the rift with very little time/financial investment. There is no incentive for a permanently banned player to reform.  If anything, they just get bitter for losing their main account and care even less about the Summoner's Code. 

I think 2-week bans are more effective because the player knows that they will get their prized account back. Re-applying 2-week bans on new offenses would be very effective at curbing behavior as compared to the perm-ban solution, which removes their incentive to reform completely.

Of course, but what you're saying still doesn't help in the context of what I said. Care to elaborate?

You can never control what other people do or don’t do in a game. You’re going to have teammates who are bad. You’re going to have teammates who flame. You’re going to have teammates who troll or int for dumb reasons or no reason at all, and there’s nothing you can say or do that will make them behave any differently. 

It doesn’t do you any good to let yourself get worked up about them. The best thing you can do is accept that these kind of games do happen and will happen again in the future, and that in the grand scheme of things, despite how awful the experience is in the moment, a single shitty match is so insignificant in your whole League experience. It isn’t worth getting upset over, much less losing an account you’ve spent so much time and money on.

I agree with your general sentiment, but I take issue with the fact that the typical solution on these boards is just to mute a player that's causing issues. Of course, you don't "control" what other players do, but decisions like muting do influence those players. It has been my experience on my fresh account that I've encountered more trolls/griefers, since muting all. I'm not 100% sure that this implies causality, but it seems like a reasonable assumption.

I do believe it is a tactic, I remember they used to wait until you had a healthy champ pool before even attempting a punishment, now they just do it left and right, so I vote with my wallet, by never giving them anything.

Riot has tried indefinite chat restrictions. Affected players resorted to other methods of being toxic. Having been permabanned, created a new account, and - in effect - chat restricted yourself, I would not be surprised if you were resorting to other methods of being toxic and bothering your team.

Riot has also tried repeated temporary suspensions. Affected players simply earned repeated temporary suspensions on an ongoing basis rather than eventually reforming. Since removing toxicity is the goal, such players are now permabanned after two chat restrictions (for chat-related offenses that don't include zero-tolerance phrases) and a single two-week suspension. Most permabanned players don't return, so that's good progress on the goal. Some players, such as yourself, do return on new accounts to continue to be toxic, but there's not a lot Riot can do about that unless the player is a highly-visible streamer who streams all their games, in which case Riot may issue an ID ban. Riot monitors such players' streams and manually bans any account those players use.

TL;DR: You are incorrect.

I can't say I ever use mute all, but that does sound strange. There's not really a great way to stop someone from trolling/feeding in a game, unless you go all Minority Report on them. 

The only constant in any of these games will always be you. So if you feel like you're getting tilted, take a break or do some stress relief. Otherwise, just play your game.

Is it true that I have a higher chance of being matched with banned players, even in Solo/Duo queue as a result of my prior account? How is that remotely fair? Someone's rating should be based on the standard deviation within the entire play base.. is this a joke? 

Also, you're saying I'm wrong about this, but I haven't really had significant issues with League of Legends player behavior until the last few seasons. I'm wrong if what you're saying is factual about why their previous systems "didn't work", but is that really true? Can you back that up with evidence? I'm pretty unconvinced that the methods employed now are nearly as effective as you claim. 

Guess my pseudo-toxicity through the way I click my champ around the map is really getting on the other players nerves, clearly, that's the lowest common denominator here. If Riot intentionally botches my matchmaking, this whole thing suddenly makes a lot of sense.

I'm not much for muting but I always tell people I muted them so they stop desperately seeking my attention and approval.
